item.title: Docker domestic image proxy failure
item.description:
Deploying Docker on domestic servers. If the company doesn’t provide an image registry, developers must first configure a domestic mirror acceleration address. Today, I configured a mirror acceleration address on a server, but it consistently fails to pull images.

Error message:

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

Troubleshooting and Repair Attempts

Initially, I attempted to switch to an alternative mirror address hoping to resolve the issue, but it proved ineffective; the problem persists

Immediately, I began modifying the local DNS configuration, attempting to find a breakthrough at the network resolution level; unfortunately, after some debugging, the fault persisted

The local network’s stability is now questionable, so I switched to my phone’s hotspot to bypass potential issues. However, the problem persists unchanged – a frustrating result.

Problems spreading

We have several servers available, all with Docker environments installed. Attempting to pull images from them proved unsuccessful; the error messages were identical across all devices, indicating a systemic issue rather than a problem with a single server.

Further investigation revealed that the mirror proxy appeared to have failed instantly. Switching quickly to an overseas machine proved successful, and thankfully, image pulling resumed normally. This suggests the issue likely lies within the domestic network link or related configurations.

Strategic adjustment: Circumventing solutions

To overcome obstacles in accessing domestic images, and with foreign mirrors accessible, we’ve decided on a workaround to expedite project progress. We will first switch to a foreign server to pull the necessary images, then push them to a domestic mirror repository, effectively creating a “data bridge.”

Meanwhile, the Dockerfile was modified to replace the image address with one suitable for domestic environments, and the image was rebuilt and successfully deployed

item.title: The End of the Era of Wild Capitalism: The League of Legends Esports Era Concludes
item.description:
The esports industry has experienced rapid growth over the past decade, becoming a significant cultural phenomenon worldwide. Games like League of Legends (LOL) have not only provided players with competitive entertainment but also fueled capital investment, driving the development of various esports platforms and events. However, this trajectory is now entering a gradual decline alongside the influx of capital and the rise of the pan-entertainment industry. The rise and fall of Panda TV, as well as the competition between Douyu and Huya, mark the end of an era of “wild capitalism,” suggesting shifts in the favorable conditions for the esports industry.

Chapter 1: The Rise of Esports and Capital Investment

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

The early esports industry had humble beginnings, particularly in China. Many players participated in competitions for games like StarCraft and Dota fueled by their passion. However, esports truly began to rise with the release and promotion of League of Legends. After League of Legends officially entered the Chinese market in 2011, esports gradually evolved from a niche community into part of mainstream culture. Especially starting in 2013, the LPL (Chinese professional league) steadily developed, making League of Legends the cornerstone of China’s esports industry.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

2015 marked a turning point for the esports industry in China. The influx of capital transformed esports from simple competitions into a much larger ecosystem. Panda TV, as one example, became a product of excess capital. Founded with investment from Wang Sicong, Panda TV rapidly gained popularity by attracting viewers and users with its innovative content and substantial investments. However, this also exemplified the “barbaric” influx of capital – a relentless pursuit that often lacks patience and long-term vision. While significant short-term achievements were made through considerable financial and human resources, Panda TV ultimately declared bankruptcy in 2019 due to management issues and overreliance on capital.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

The fall of Panda TV did not lead to a decline in the esports streaming industry, but rather spurred the rise of platforms like Douyu and Huya. These two giants quickly became leaders in the esports sector, with increasingly fierce competition between them. Douyu initially gained prominence through livestreaming League of Legends professional matches and signing top streamers, setting a benchmark for esports broadcasting. Huya, by increasing investment in esports events and diversifying its platform, gradually narrowed the gap with Douyu.

Capital played a significant role in this process. Bilibili successfully went public in 2018, and Huya also conducted an IPO that same year. The rapid flow of capital led to high industry concentration and intense competition between platforms for streamers and copyrights, resulting in a “capital war.”

Chapter 2: The Convergence of Pan-Entertainment and Esports

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

With increased investment in the esports industry, esports platforms are gradually diversifying their content. Esports hosts are expanding beyond game commentary and event streaming to include various entertainment formats such as singing, dancing, and interactive live streams. This has resulted in a richer content ecosystem centered around esports but incorporating diverse entertainment elements.

However, the trend towards broad entertainment has brought problems—the originally focused gaming culture of esports is gradually being marginalized, replaced by a trend prioritizing entertainment above all else. This shift has caused some viewers who were deeply passionate about esports culture to feel alienated, and capital is increasingly turning its attention to other entertainment sectors. Excessive investment and profit-seeking are blurring the essence of the esports industry, weakening the core value proposition centered on competition.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

With the rise of short video platforms, live streaming platforms, and other pan-entertainment industries, capital has gradually shifted funds from esports to broader entertainment content. Consequently, giants like Tencent, Alibaba, and ByteDance are no longer solely reliant on esports projects for profit but have increased investment in areas such as film, music, and short videos. Notably, ByteDance’s rise, fueled by the explosive growth of platforms like Douyin, has overshadowed esports’ prominence.

Chapter 3: League of Legends’ “Generational Shift”: The Fading Era of Dividends

Since League of Legends entered the Chinese market in 2011, it has become synonymous with the esports industry, fostering countless professional players, teams, and events, and driving a massive esports ecosystem. However, over a decade later, as a leading project in Chinese esports, League of Legends is entering a stage of generational transition. Notably, its influence has been gradually declining in recent years, even showing signs of significant decline.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are! The most noticeable change is a generational shift in the player base. Initially, esports’ rapid growth was fueled by a large cohort of young players, many of whom became professional players or viewers thanks to League of Legends. This generation grew up during a period of “demographic dividend,” immersed in the game’s competitive appeal and driving industry expansion. However, as time passed, these players matured, entered society, and shifted their focus towards other aspects of life and careers. Simultaneously, younger generations show less enthusiasm for League of Legends, resulting in an evident age gap and declining interest within the esports audience.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are! Despite numerous updates and revisions, League of Legends’ content innovation is struggling to keep pace. Annual version updates, hero balance adjustments, and the introduction of new gameplay features have failed to fundamentally address players’ need for novelty. Simultaneously, the MOBA market is becoming saturated, and other game genres like Honor of Kings and Peacekeeper Elite have rapidly gained popularity, diverting a significant number of players away from League of Legends. This competitive landscape has left League of Legends perpetually in a “chaser” role.

Conclusion: What is the future of the esports industry?

The esports industry is like a skyscraper that seemingly sprung up overnight. Excessive capital wanders within the internet sector, seeking the next opportunity, and esports has become one of their targets. Leveraging China’s demographic dividend, the industry achieved rapid success, but this success lacks a solid foundation. Over-investment in capital, talent shortages, and weak game content are all hindering healthy development.

Before college, I didn’t play many games. League of Legends accompanied a generation’s growth; I watched so many finals. As an outsider, comparing Chinese and Korean players—especially Faker—Chinese players always felt hesitant during major tournaments. I understand the psychological pressure on players, but after more than ten years of development in this industry, mental health should be prioritized by teams. However, it hasn’t been, and gameplay still relies on players’ innate talent.

item.title: From Games to Family: Why We Gradually Drift Away from Virtual Worlds as We Grow Up
item.description:
What were the happiest times playing games – sneaking to play Tank Battle, Super Mario, and Contra on our family’s TV as a child, or secretly playing Age of Empires on our family’s computer with my cousin, or later in college, playing Devil May Cry and League of Legends with my roommates?

Childhood had no worries, and when you played, you were completely absorbed in it – a level of immersion that’s impossible to find again as an adult

As times change and society progresses, we who were once active in virtual worlds are gradually realizing that the game platform filled with joy and competition seems to be drifting away from our lives. The disconnection of game social links, accompanied by players’ gradual departure, is not only due to technological advancements and the replacement of games themselves, but also because of a shift in our life’s focus. As we grow older, we become busy with marriage and having children, and the main thread of life gradually shifts from personal entertainment to family responsibilities. Today, let’s discuss the underlying reasons behind this trend.

The Disappearance of Gaming Socialization: A Tug-of-War Between Virtual and Real Worlds

For many, games weren’t just entertainment during their youth; they were a social outlet. Popular online multiplayer games offered challenges and competition while connecting players worldwide, creating virtual communities. Playing dungeons and team battles with friends was part of life back then, as were late-night voice chats and sharing daily experiences – memories we cherish.

However, with time, more and more players have found that this virtual social experience lacks lasting appeal. As games are updated and new platforms emerge, players increasingly find more interactive ways to socialize outside of gaming. In-game friendships gradually fade from view, and many previously active social connections within the game eventually dissolve.

Games and Responsibility: A Shift in Life’s Focus After Adulthood

Entering adulthood, responsibilities gradually increase. Many young people once invested significant time in games, but with the start of their careers or shared living/family formation, these previously essential leisure activities are squeezed by life’s obligations. Marriage, having children, and even caring for parents – these major responsibilities require choices regarding energy and time.

Gaming has become a thing of the past, replaced by the prioritization of family life. Many young people who once “struggled” in games are gradually realizing that real-life is the most important matter. Especially after having children, the focus of their lives shifts completely to family, and gaming is pushed to the periphery.

From Games to Family: How Changes in Life Affect Our Entertainment Choices

In our life experiences, family is one of the most important components. Once entering family life, time and energy become more specific and limited. To care for children and spend time with their partners, many young parents find they no longer have enough time to focus on games they once loved. Sometimes, they even lose interest in game updates and new releases. Gradually, social media platforms and offline interactions with friends and family become the preferred way for many people to socialize.

This doesn’t mean we’ve completely abandoned entertainment, but rather chosen ways more suitable for our current life stage. Many friends who used to connect through games may now maintain contact via other means—family gatherings, meals together, or short trips—due to diverging life paths.

Farewell to the virtual world: How do we view this shift?

For many who once immersed themselves in gaming, saying goodbye to game-related social connections isn’t easy. That virtual world, which brought us joy and a sense of accomplishment, has become part of our memories. However, farewell doesn’t mean severing ties completely; it means making different choices as life changes, balancing our roles in the real world. As we mature from youthful boys to responsible adults, while games still hold value, they can no longer be the main theme of our lives.

In reality, this shift reflects a facet of human adaptability—our ability to adjust our focus and lifestyle according to different stages. When responsibilities and family become central to life, gaming socialization is no longer a priority but rather an occasional pastime.

Future games: may usher in another wave of “sense of belonging.”

Of course, with social development and technological advancements, the forms and content of games are constantly evolving. For example, modern online multiplayer games are increasingly moving towards more relaxed and flexible approaches, and some even prioritize family interaction and parent-child relationships. In the future, we may see more game formats that better integrate into family life and provide players with healthier, more balanced social experiences.

Just as many people still feel nostalgia and passion when talking about “childhood games,” perhaps we, in the future, will also unexpectedly revisit those past games, bringing new understanding and experience, and re-enter that virtual world

Life is changing, but love remains

Whether it’s games or family, life’s changes consistently accompany our growth. We gradually realize that while virtual worlds offer endless joy and excitement, we ultimately return to reality, to the warmest place – home. There’s no need to regret leaving games, as each stage of life has its own unique meaning. These changes are what make us more complete.

item.title: Hong Kong Stock Exchange, History of Cryptocurrency Development
item.description:
With Donald Trump’s re-election as US President, virtual currency has once again entered the public consciousness. Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) has also been actively developing related businesses; here’s a brief overview of HKEX’s virtual currency development history.

Reviewing the contract details, it’s clear that futures were initially introduced, which is reasonable given their better liquidity and ease of attracting institutional investors. The subsequent introduction of spot ETFs was also logical, as ETFs are a more readily accepted investment tool.

Cryptocurrency List

The Hong Kong Stock Exchange’s market data doesn’t provide a tag to distinguish whether a contract is for virtual currency, but it can be determined by the contract name. The official transaction list does provide corresponding subcategories INLINE_CODE_0.

https://www.hkex.com.hk/Market-Data/Securities-Prices/Exchange-Traded-Products?sc_lang=en&asset=virtualasset

December 16, 2022

Hong Kong Exchange Welcomes First Asia-Based Crypto ETFs Listing

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) today (Friday) welcomed the listing of Asia’s first cryptocurrency ETFs, further expanding its product ecosystem and providing more choices for Hong Kong and international investors

Two new ETFs launched today — China Southern East Funds Management’s Bitcoin Futures ETF (stock code: 3066) and Ethereum Futures ETF (stock code: 3068) — are managed by China Southern East Asset Management Co., Ltd. They track standardized, cash-settled Bitcoin futures contracts and Ethereum futures contracts traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME).

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Chief Operating Officer and Co-Head of Markets, Nicole Yau, stated: “The two newly listed cryptocurrency ETFs add to Hong Kong’s increasingly rich and diverse ecosystem of exchange-traded products. These new products will provide investors in Asia with their first opportunity to participate in digital asset investments, reflecting our focus on the digital economy and market demand. We look forward to welcoming more thematic ETFs and digital asset products in the coming months.”

ETFs are one of the fastest-growing businesses under Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, with a constantly expanding and increasingly diverse range of products. In 2022, this included the launch of its first Metaverse ETF, first carbon futures ETF, and first blockchain ETF, as well as the inclusion of ETFs in the Shanghai–Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme for the first time.

The average daily turnover of Exchange Traded Products (ETPs), including ETFs and leveraged/inverse products, on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange for the first eleven months of this year was HK$11.8 billion, a 50% increase from HK$7.8 billion in the same period last year, reflecting growing investor demand. As of November 2022, there were 168 ETPs listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange with a total market capitalization of HK$373.5 billion.

April 30, 2024

Hong Kong Exchange welcomes the listing of the first spot virtual asset ETFs

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) today (Tuesday) welcomed the listing of Asia’s first spot virtual asset ETFs, expanding Hong Kong’s product range and providing investors with greater choice, solidifying Hong Kong’s position as a leading ETF market in Asia

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Head of Securities Product Development Robert Lo said, “The newly launched virtual asset spot ETF will enrich Hong Kong’s diverse and vibrant ETF market ecosystem, providing investors with investment opportunities in a new asset class. Following the successful launch of virtual asset futures ETFs a year ago, Asia’s first virtual asset spot ETFs will further enhance the variety and liquidity of products traded on Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing. We look forward to continuing to work closely with market participants to introduce more new products into our internationalized market.”

Investor demand for the first batch of virtual asset futures ETFs launched in 2022 has been strong, with robust trading volume. The daily turnover of Hong Kong-listed virtual asset futures ETFs increased from HK$8.9 million in 2023 to HK$51.3 million in Q1 2024, accompanied by net inflows of HK$529 million.

The exchange trading of products (including ETFs, leveraged and inverse products) is one of the fastest-growing markets on Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, with a continuously expanding range of product types. Sixteen new ETF products were added in 2023 and Q1 2024, including Asia’s first Saudi Arabia ETF and Hong Kong’s first exchange-traded options ETFs. There are currently 179 ETFs listed in Hong Kong.

October 28, 2024

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing is launching a series of virtual asset indices

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) today (Monday) announced the launch of the HKEX Virtual Asset Index Series on November 15, 2024. This index series will provide a reliable benchmark for the rapidly growing asset class of virtual assets, supporting Hong Kong’s development as Asia’s leading digital asset hub.

This index series will provide a transparent and reliable benchmark for the pricing of Bitcoin and Ethereum in Asian time zones, aiming to establish a unified reference price for virtual assets and resolve price discrepancies across global exchanges

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing CEO Nicolas Aguzin said, “We are pleased to launch the Hong Kong Exchange Virtual Asset Index Series to meet regional demand for this rapidly growing asset class. By providing a transparent and reliable real-time benchmark, we aim to help investors make informed decisions, support the healthy development of the virtual asset ecosystem, and solidify Hong Kong’s position as an international financial center.”

The launch of this index series is part of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing’s commitment to exploring emerging areas, supporting the development of Hong Kong’s financial technology while also providing investors with important benchmark tools and solutions in a constantly evolving market environment

The index series will include reference indices for Bitcoin and Ethereum, as well as reference exchange rates

The reference rate is calculated based on a weighted average of 24-hour trading volumes in Bitcoin or Ethereum, aggregated from major cryptocurrency exchanges and priced in USD. It’s designed for the settlement of financial products and calculated daily at 4:00 PM Hong Kong time.

This index series will be the first in Hong Kong to comply with EU Benchmark Regulation (BMR), co-managed and calculated by a UK-registered benchmark administrator and virtual asset data and index provider, CCData

The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government issued a policy statement in 2022 aiming to foster a vibrant virtual asset industry and ecosystem in Hong Kong. The launch of the Hong Kong Exchange’s Virtual Asset Index series will help increase public understanding of virtual asset investment trends by providing real-time data and daily reference prices in the Asian time zone.

Further details regarding the design and calculation methods of the index series will be released as appropriate

item.title: Increased scrutiny of third-party investment advisors; will those behind the TikTok stock trading scheme face repercussions?
item.description:
The sledgehammer is falling

Brokerage services, boosted by short videos, may be entering a period of rapid growth

In late September, following a surge in A-share market performance, Douyin’s stock recommendations received widespread attention

Several financial commentators, including “Da Lan,” gained popularity on Douyin, indirectly causing some volatility in the capital market

The rise of popular financial commentators is also supported by third-party investment advisory firms

According to sources, many third-party investment advisory firms operate multiple accounts on short video platforms, using traffic strategies to attract viewers to watch their educational videos and boost enthusiasm for purchasing related investment advisory products

Rumors suggest that a certain third-party investment advisory firm earned 1 billion yuan in revenue this October alone, exceeding its earnings for the entire first half of the year

But “good times” are facing more uncertainties

Since November, various departments have issued documents requiring securities service providers to strengthen compliance management of social media accounts

On November 15th evening, Tonghua Shun (300033.SZ) announced that its subsidiary was penalized by the securities regulatory commission for livestreaming activities involving implied stock recommendations This could be signaling that regulators are tightening their oversight The promotion of third-party investment advisory firms, including Nine Square Wisdom Investment (9636.HK), may face increased pressure

Close monitoring

The rise of short video platforms like Douyin has amplified emotional expression and indirectly influenced trading behavior

According to data from Jullian Analytics, during the period of September 27th to October 8th, when transaction volume reached a new high, Douyin’s A-share keyword search index soared from 4.2384 million to 12.7786 million, more than doubling

The actions of third-party investment advisors are attracting regulatory attention amid this situation

Brokerage employees recommending individual stocks during livestreams is a frequent violation

On November 8th, the Guangdong Securities Regulatory Bureau took regulatory measures to suspend the acceptance of new clients from a company due to instances of “suggesting stock recommendations” during its livestream

On the evening of November 14th, the Guangdong Securities and Futures Industry Association issued a notice titled “Inadequate Live Stream Control Results in Business Suspension,” directly pointing out that certain institutions with securities advisory qualifications had inadequate controls during live stream promotional activities, including recommending specific stocks

Live stock recommendations are prohibited. Live streaming falls under public media dissemination, and live streamers, regardless of whether they are registered securities investment advisors, are not permitted to recommend individual stocks during broadcasts. - Guangdong Securities & Futures Association.

This is not an isolated case

On November 7th, a penalty notice disclosed by the Shanghai Securities Regulatory Bureau also included one case involving illegal stock recommendations on social media platforms

An investigation by regulators revealed that Wang Yong, an investment consultant at Haitun Securities Investment Consulting Co., Ltd. Shanghai Branch, published misleading video content on WeChat Video Number, which violated professional conduct guidelines.

The Shanghai Securities Regulatory Bureau took supervisory measures, issuing a warning letter to Wang Yong

According to sources, some unqualified investment advisors who were recommending stocks on Douyin (TikTok) by affiliating with brokerages have been suspended

Some individuals in the industry are doing livestreams on Douyin, operating under brokerage firms to obtain investment consultant qualifications. They then use these livestreams to attract customers and sell investment consultant product packages offline. However, they were suspended after being caught recommending specific stocks during a livestream. Reputable brokerages typically only discuss sector conditions in their educational livestreams, but avoid mentioning individual stocks.

Currently, regulators are closely monitoring illegal stock recommendations on social media

Recently, the Shenzhen Securities Regulatory Bureau has notified that some institutions or individuals within the industry have been found to be engaging in illegal stock recommendations and other violations through self-media. To further regulate the operation and management of securities investment consulting agencies’ self-media within its jurisdiction, each agency should strengthen their own self-media operations management.

This may bring more challenges to the promotion of third-party wealth management services

Traffic businesses are illegal

Whether investors lured into the market by short videos have made money remains to be seen, but as “water sellers,” third-party investment advisory firms are already seeing their value rise in the secondary market

As a leading player in online investment education, Jiufang Intelligent Investment’s market capitalization has surged from 287.8 million yuan in early September to 1.2464 billion yuan as of the close on November 13th, representing a gain of 333.08% over 49 trading days

The mid-year report shows that in the first half of this year, Jiufang Zhi Tou conducted brand exposure on social media platforms like Douyin and Xiaohongshu, reaching 488 accounts and 0.46 billion followers by the end of June

For example, “Hong Bangzhu” (Mr. Hong), as Chief Investment Consultant for Jiufang Zhito, has 2.26 million followers on Douyin.

We focus on MCN operations, prioritizing users and collaboratively driving the comprehensive development of traffic, brand, and product. Jiu Fang Zhi Tou notes that by deeply integrating new media tools like live streaming and short videos, leveraging AI technology to build fan networks, and actively exploring e-commerce models, we can effectively achieve efficient conversion of traffic.

Jiufang Zhitu’s advisory courses range in price from several thousand to over ten thousand yuan. Their most expensive package, “Super Investor,” is priced at 139,600 yuan/six months and includes exclusive insights and private advisor services.

However, Jiumfang Intelligence Investment’s advisory products have a refund rate exceeding 10%

In the first half of 2024, the refund rates for Jiu Fang Zhi Tou’s flagship series and Qinyulong series were 14.7% and 18.5%, respectively

Whether Jiufang Intelligent Investment’s business expansion will be affected remains to be seen amidst regulatory scrutiny

Recent media reports indicate that accounts under third-party investment advisors like Jiufang Zhi Tou have been affected

An upstream open-source development platform prior to release First noticed the open-source operating system lifecycle

It’s expired, what’s the problem? Besides security issues, DNF isn’t working. I noticed it failed when I recently installed a tool, and checking the mirror source revealed that it has expired.

Introduction to CentOS Stream

Positioning and Role

CentOS Stream sits between Fedora Linux (upstream development) and RHEL (downstream development), acting as a bridge

It can be seen as a version for experiencing the latest Red Hat Enterprise Linux features, suitable for early adopters

Birth and Background

As time passed, Red Hat began seeking more effective ways to develop its enterprise-level Linux platform and launched CentOS Stream

After CentOS 8 reached its end-of-life in late 2021, CentOS Stream continued to receive updates as its successor and has become the future direction of the CentOS project

Features and Advantages

CentOS Stream is a rolling-release Linux distribution offering faster updates. It provides greater transparency and opportunities for community, partner, and customer involvement, allowing users to contribute to Red Hat Enterprise Linux more quickly and directly.

The content of CentOS Stream is software that Red Hat intends to include in a future stable version of RHEL, providing a stable ABI/API for community members for development and testing

Use Cases & Target Users

CentOS Stream is suitable for CentOS users who want to continue receiving the latest Linux feature updates, as well as developers and partners who wish to participate in Red Hat Enterprise Linux development

It also aims to help community members, Red Hat partners, and others fully leverage innovative open-source programs within a more stable and predictable Linux ecosystem

item.title: County-level Brahmin: Big Shots in Small Towns
item.description:
Recently, Teacher Da Bing has become very popular on Douyin. You often see accounts sharing clips from her livestreams. During one livestream, a listener asked, “Teacher Da Bing, I want to sell my house in Xi’an and return home to relax.” Da Bing replied, “At your age, in your thirties, you can’t just ‘lie flat.’ Your parents are aging, your children aren’t established yet, and even returning to your hometown, you’ll still have to deal with the complexities of a small county town.”

Regardless of whether the view is right or wrong, what does this word mean?

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

In many small county towns, people often talk about “county Brahmin” – their existence feels like a symbol of the local society. They are not necessarily religious figures or individuals with impressive titles, but rather seemingly ordinary yet influential people. They represent “power, status, and voice” in a small place, symbolizing a certain stratum within that county town.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

Initially, we need to understand that “Brahmin” originally referred to the highest stratum of Indian society, representing wisdom, authority, and spiritual supremacy. However, in Chinese county towns, the term “county town Brahmin” lacks such complex religious connotations; it’s more a metaphor for a social phenomenon.

Simply put, “county-level Brahmin” refers to individuals who hold cultural authority within a county, such as teachers, doctors, prominent local merchants, and officials. Although their positions may seem ordinary, in the relatively closed environment of a county, they possess a comparatively high social status or, more accurately, considerable influence on local opinions and actions.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

In the county town, almost every industry has these “Brahmins.” They might be:

  • Especially teachers with decades of experience in local areas, who may not be graduates of prestigious universities, but deeply understand how to build credibility through knowledge and are widely respected
  • Officials in county-level cities, such as deputy county commissioners and section chiefs, control certain resources and power. Despite their relatively low positions, due to the limited scope of their authority, they can become influential figures within their localities.
  • Owners in some county-level cities, though their businesses may not be large, hold considerable wealth and local influence. They might run a couple of well-known small enterprises and have significant sway within the county.

These individuals, though not prominent compared to elites or officials in big cities, hold a status almost equivalent to “cultural elders” or “power centers” within this small county-level society

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

To truly understand the meaning of “county-level Brahmins,” we must consider the unique environment of county towns. Here, information flows more slowly than in big cities, and social mobility is relatively fixed. These “Brahmins” often gain influence through long-term engagement with the locality, accumulating reputation, knowledge, and networks. They impact various aspects of local politics, economy, and culture.

  1. In smaller areas, particularly where the education system may not be well-developed and ordinary people have limited choices, local “Brahmin” figures subtly shape the cultural atmosphere through knowledge imparted in classrooms, media explanations, and even social interactions

  2. Due to the limited population and resources in county-level towns, these “Brahmins” are often key controllers of local resources. Their influence is pervasive, affecting everything from social welfare and policy implementation to project approvals. Their power of speech and decision-making allows them to hold a significant position within the local community.

  3. In a relatively closed small society, interpersonal relationships are often crucial. These “county-level Brahmins” control the flow of information and allocation of resources by establishing strong social networks, allowing them to play a decisive role at critical moments.

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

While “county-level Brahmins” are often respected and revered, this elevated status is not without its problems. In modern society, it’s easy to see that many of these “Brahmins” in county towns may lack genuine ability and innovative spirit, instead maintaining their position through hereditary relationships and resource monopolies. With the development of informatization, their power is gradually being eroded, and new social mobility is beginning to reshape the landscape of small counties.

Overall, “County-Level Brahmins” is a fascinating social phenomenon that reflects the power and cultural structures within local societies. While their “power” may not directly threaten national governance, they are undoubtedly influential figures within their localities. In this era of rapid information flow and accelerating social change, these “Brahmins” in county towns may be facing unprecedented challenges.

item.title: Slow efficiency when processing large string data in Linux backend services
item.description:
In past C++ development projects, we used a custom protocol for communication that employed a two-dimensional array structure. Due to inefficient traversal and serialization of this array when handling large amounts of data, the system experienced noticeable lag under high load, prompting feedback from the business department regarding these slowdowns.

Issue identification

During troubleshooting, we first performed a performance analysis of the system. We found that CPU usage increased significantly and response times lengthened when processing large amounts of data. Analyzing system logs revealed numerous serialization operations, which were inefficient when handling two-dimensional arrays, leading to decreased system performance.

The tool’s thread analysis revealed that the logging thread spends most of its time string concatenation

The key takeaway today is that different accumulation methods have vastly different efficiencies. Legacy code used the __INLINE_CODE_0 operator, which frequently creates temporary objects and is very inefficient—the kind of inefficiency you know is bad but don’t realize just how bad it is.

Demo verification

We extracted the business logic based on the project code and created a simple demo to verify the efficiency of string concatenation. We compared the efficiency while compiling and running it in windows 下的 vs2022 编译器，INLINE_CODE_2 下的 INLINE_CODE_3 编译器，INLINE_CODE_4 mode.

Key points

The project uses method four. Before receiving the test data, readers can first consider which approach is most efficient and which is least efficient. I was still surprised by the results.

  1. Concatenate each field directly into a string
  2. Using streams (concatenating) to join each field is more efficient, especially when dealing with large amounts of data
  3. Pre-allocating sufficient memory for strings reduces the overhead of memory reallocation, thereby improving performance
  4. Creating a new temporary string object for each concatenation degrades performance, especially during large-scale concatenations, as it involves repeated memory allocation and copying

Based on the results, the project selected the least efficient method

Furthermore, let’s analyze the optimization efficiency of different platforms’ compilers. Microsoft’s compiler falls short in this regard.

Running the code on different machines makes direct comparison of the data meaningless; instead, compare the differences between different concatenation methods

Complete code 

#include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
#include <random>
#include <chrono>
#include <sstream>
#include <iomanip>

typedef std::vector<std::string> DataRow;
typedef std::vector<DataRow> DataGroup;

struct ResponsePackage
{
    std::string ErrorInfo;
    DataRow Head;
    std::string ClientId;
    std::string UUID;
    std::string MsgID;
    std::string SessionID;
    std::string ExtraInfo1;
    std::string ExtraInfo2;
    DataGroup DataBody;
};

// Generate specified length of random string
std::string generateRandomString(size_t length)
{
    const char charset[] = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789";
    const size_t max_index = sizeof(charset) - 1;
    std::string random_string;
    random_string.reserve(length);

    std::random_device rd;
    std::mt19937 generator(rd());
    std::uniform_int_distribution<> distribution(0, max_index);

    for (size_t i = 0; i < length; ++i)
    {
        random_string += charset[distribution(generator)];
    }

    return random_string;
}

void create_large_string()
{
    // Example request package with 50 fields
    ResponsePackage requestPackage;

    requestPackage.Head = {
        "Field1", "Field2", "Field3", "Field4", "Field5",
        "Field6", "Field7", "Field8", "Field9", "Field10",
        "Field11", "Field12", "Field13", "Field14", "Field15",
        "Field16", "Field17", "Field18", "Field19", "Field20",
        "Field21", "Field22", "Field23", "Field24", "Field25",
        "Field26", "Field27", "Field28", "Field29", "Field30",
        "Field31", "Field32", "Field33", "Field34", "Field35",
        "Field36", "Field37", "Field38", "Field39", "Field40",
        "Field41", "Field42", "Field43", "Field44", "Field45",
        "Field46", "Field47", "Field48", "Field49", "Field50"
    };

    requestPackage.ClientId = "ClientID";
    requestPackage.UUID = "UUID";
    requestPackage.MsgID = "MsgID";
    requestPackage.SessionID = "SessionID";
    requestPackage.ExtraInfo1 = "ExtraInfo1";
    requestPackage.ExtraInfo2 = "ExtraInfo2";

    // Start timing for data generation
    auto start_gen = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();

    // Generate 10,000 rows of data, each with 50 fields
    for (size_t i = 0; i < 10000; ++i)
    {
        DataRow dataRow(50, "This is a test string");
        requestPackage.DataBody.push_back(dataRow);
    }

    // End timing for data generation
    auto end_gen = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
    std::chrono::duration<double> duration_gen = end_gen - start_gen;

    // Display result generation time
    std::cout << "\n----------------------------------------\n";
    std::cout << "Data Generation Time: " << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3) << duration_gen.count() << " seconds.\n";
    std::cout << "----------------------------------------\n";

    // Data merging using different methods
    std::cout << "\n----------------------------------------\n";
    std::cout << "Data Merging Performance:\n";
    std::cout << "----------------------------------------\n";

    {
        // Method 1: Using '+=' string concatenation
        auto start_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::string bodys("");
        for (auto& vec : requestPackage.DataBody)
        {
            std::string body("This is a test string");
            for (auto& item : vec)
            {
                body += item + " ";
            }
            bodys += body + "\n";
        }
        auto end_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::chrono::duration<double> duration_merge = end_merge - start_merge;
        std::cout << "+ Data merging (+=) took: " << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3) << duration_merge.count() << " seconds.\n";
    }

    {
        // Method 2: Using ostringstream
        auto start_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::ostringstream bodys;
        for (auto& vec : requestPackage.DataBody)
        {
            std::ostringstream body;
            body << "This is a test string";
            for (auto& item : vec)
            {
                body << item << " ";
            }
            bodys << body.str() << "\n";
        }
        auto end_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::chrono::duration<double> duration_merge = end_merge - start_merge;
        std::cout << "+ ostringstream Data merging took: " << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3) << duration_merge.count() << " seconds.\n";
    }

    {
        // Method 3: Pre-allocated memory
        auto start_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::string bodys;
        bodys.reserve(1000 * 50 * 20); // Pre-allocate enough memory
        for (auto& vec : requestPackage.DataBody)
        {
            std::string body("This is a test string");
            body.reserve(50 * 20); // Pre-allocate memory for each row
            for (auto& item : vec)
            {
                body += item + " ";
            }
            bodys += body + "\n";
        }
        auto end_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::chrono::duration<double> duration_merge = end_merge - start_merge;
        std::cout << "+ Pre-reserved Data merging took: " << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3) << duration_merge.count() << " seconds.\n";
    }

    {
        // Method 4: Using 'bodys = bodys + body + "\n"'
        auto start_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::string bodys("");
        for (auto& vec : requestPackage.DataBody)
        {
            std::string body("This is a test string");
            for (auto& item : vec)
            {
                body = body + item + " "; // Note the use of 'body = body + item'
            }
            bodys = bodys + body + "\n"; // Again, using 'bodys = bodys + body'
        }
        auto end_merge = std::chrono::high_resolution_clock::now();
        std::chrono::duration<double> duration_merge = end_merge - start_merge;
        std::cout << "+ Data merging (bodys = bodys + body + \"\\n\") took: " << std::fixed << std::setprecision(3) << duration_merge.count() << " seconds.\n";
    }

    std::cout << "\n----------------------------------------\n";
    std::cout << "Data Merging Complete.\n";
    std::cout << "----------------------------------------\n";
}

int main()
{
    try
    {
        create_large_string();
    }
    catch (const std::exception& e)
    {
        std::cerr << "Caught exception: " << e.what() << std::endl;
    }

    std::cout << "\nProgram finished.\n";
    return 0;
}

item.title: Lambda expression parameter lifetime in C++
item.description:
In C++, lambda expressions are convenient anonymous functions that can capture external variables and use them internally. This makes lambdas a flexible programming tool. However, the lifecycle of lambda expression parameters is an aspect requiring special attention, particularly when capturing and passing arguments.

Lambda expression parameter lifecycle

The lifetime of lambda expression parameters generally mirrors that of other C++ functions. Parameters exist during the function call and end when the call completes. However, due to potential capture of external variables, parameter lifetimes can also be affected by the capturing method.

The relationship between capture and parameter lifecycle

Capturing External Variables

C++ lambda expressions allow capturing external variables in two ways:

  • By value capture, the values of external variables are copied into the lambda, and the lifecycle of these copies is controlled by the lambda’s lifecycle
  • Through capturing references, external variable references are preserved; lambda’s references point to the original external variables, and their lifecycle depends on the external variables
int x = 10;
auto lambda_by_value = [x]() { std::cout << x << std::endl; };  // 捕获x的副本
auto lambda_by_reference = [&x]() { std::cout << x << std::endl; };  // 捕获x的引用

lambda_by_value();  // 打印10
lambda_by_reference();  // 打印10

The lifecycle of captured variables is as follows:

  • When a variable is captured, its value is copied into the lambda; when the lambda’s lifecycle ends, this copy is destroyed
  • Lambda functions hold references to external variables

Lambda Parameters

Lambda parameters are similar to regular function parameters, with a lifecycle limited to the lambda function body. They are created upon lambda invocation and terminate when the invocation is complete.

auto lambda = [](int a, int b) {
    std::cout << a + b << std::endl;
};
lambda(5, 10);  // a和b在这里是lambda的参数

In this example, aBOLD_2b are the parameters of the lambda expression; they are created when the lambda is called and destroyed after it finishes executing

Lifecycle issues when capturing external variables

Whether captured variables are valid outside of the lambda

  • Even if external variables are destroyed after a lambda call, the lambda internally still holds a copy of those variables. Therefore, the internal copy can be used safely, even if the external variables no longer exist.
int x = 10;
auto lambda = [x]() { std::cout << x << std::endl; };
x = 20;  // x 在lambda调用后修改
lambda();  // 打印10，捕获的是x的副本
  • If a lambda captures a reference to an external variable, access to that reference within the lambda depends on the lifetime of the external variable. If the external variable is destroyed before the lambda executes, it can lead to a dangling reference and undefined behavior.
int x = 10;
auto lambda = [&x]() { std::cout << x << std::endl; };
x = 20;  // x 在lambda调用前修改
lambda();  // 打印20，捕获的是x的引用

It’s crucial to ensure that captured external variables remain valid when the lambda is executed if the order of execution for lambdas is uncertain

item.title: Logitech headset driver installation failed
item.description:
If you didn’t understand these things, you wouldn’t waste hours troubleshooting; you would contact customer service immediately

Main body

Recently, the C drive on my home desktop computer ran out of space. I allocated a 256GB SSD for it, but have been having issues with it frequently. Since moving to Shanghai, I’ve been busy with various matters, and finally found time last week to reinstall the operating system.

The system reinstall went smoothly, and installing everyday software and setting up the development environment presented no issues. A few days later, intending to relax with some games, I realized the drivers for my mouse and headset weren’t installed yet. Both devices are Logitech, so I downloaded GHUB, which automatically recognized the hardware and installed the drivers.

However, an unexpected issue occurred. The mouse driver installed smoothly, but the headset driver continuously displayed “Loading.” I suspect incompatibility between the latest version of Windows 11 and Logitech’s drivers caused the installation failure. I then began searching for information and attempting to manually install the driver, but the problem persisted.

Here’s the translation: Simply put, what is the function of each device’s driver?

  • The mouse driver mainly adjusts functions like movement speed. I rarely use macros; restoring previously saved parameters is sufficient.
  • The driver primarily functions for headphone monitoring, which is very useful during team voice communication as it allows me to hear my own voice. While the system’s microphone settings offer a similar feature, the driver implementation works better.

Despite repeated attempts, the headphones’ drivers consistently failed to load. Today, I finally thought to contact customer service for assistance and see if there was a solution. Customer service informed me that their servers have recently been experiencing issues, causing abnormal driver downloads. They are working on resolving this issue and advised me to wait until the next update when the problem should be fixed.

Although the headphone driver issue hasn’t been resolved yet, we at least know the cause, and hope it can be fixed soon

item.title: The Art of Balancing Bank Marketing Strategies with Personal Financial Management
item.description:
Recently, home renovations have significantly increased our daily expenses. We typically use credit cards and pay them off within the billing cycle. Although we have sufficient cash on hand, we prefer to keep it in money market funds for extra interest income. At the same time, to ensure financial stability, we’ve set up automatic payments to promptly repay credit card bills upon due date.

Bank status: Deposits increasing, loans decreasing

Amidst growing economic uncertainty, people are more inclined to save rather than consume or invest. This leads to increased bank deposits but also requires banks to pay higher interest rates. Conversely, reduced consumption and investment activity lowers loan demand, making it difficult for banks to generate income through lending.

To attract and retain customers, banks are compelled to offer more competitive deposit rates, further compressing their net interest margins. Simultaneously, to stimulate economic growth and consumption, the central bank may implement policies to lower benchmark interest rates, which will also affect loan rates and subsequently impact bank profitability.

Bank marketing strategies: Cultivating user habits

Repayment is approaching soon. First, Bank of Communications offered me a one-year interest-free installment plan. Shortly after, China Merchants Bank provided a 2.5% discount on installment interest, resulting in an annual rate of just 1.9%. Faced with these offers, I chose to accept the installment services from both banks.

Banks are truly investing heavily to cultivate user habits. According to the definition of a bank’s revenue stream, I should be considered a valuable client. Given the current difficulty in lending, banks are essentially preparing for potential future financial difficulties on my part by fostering my installment mindset—allowing them to earn more interest income when that time comes. After all, credit card interest rates are well-known to be high.

…and laid the groundwork for future profits

The importance of personal financial management

While bank installment offers may seem appealing, users should recognize the risks of over-relying on credit card installments. We should carefully consider our repayment ability and future financial needs to avoid falling into long-term debt for short-term convenience. Key to personal finance management is balancing current needs with future planning.

item.title: The multifaceted nature of games: A convergence of psychological development and social entertainment
item.description:
In today’s digital age, gaming has evolved beyond a simple form of entertainment and become an integral part of daily life. From a psychological perspective, games play different roles in the mental development of people across various age groups and are closely linked to social interaction and recreation.

Mental state

Young people are in a stage of exploring themselves and establishing their identity, therefore games can allow them to try on different roles and lives, satisfying curiosity and the desire for exploration. As they age, personal interests and values gradually stabilize, and games may no longer align with their life goals and interests.

Social attributes

At the same time, gaming has become a social activity, especially for young people. They make friends and build social networks through games, which serve as a bridge for socializing. However, as people age, their social circles stabilize and social needs may be met through more mature means, diminishing the role of gaming in socialization.

Taking a girl out

In China, due to a lack of relationship education, children are pressured to focus solely on academics by their parents, then immediately pushed into relationships upon graduation—a very common phenomenon

Lacking stable emotional relationships due to busy schedules, work commitments, or a lack of social skills can lead to feelings of loneliness and a desire for attention. However, by helping and protecting female players, they experience a sense of being needed and valued, achieving emotional fulfillment.

At the same time, the game’s clear interaction rules and controllable environment offer certainty and a sense of security compared to the complexity and uncertainty of real life, reducing fears about unpredictable social interactions. However, prolonged reliance on virtual gratification within games may negatively impact their ability to form and maintain healthy emotional relationships in reality.

Reality pressure

Games offer a virtual world where players can temporarily escape the pressures, challenges, or unpleasant emotions of reality. This is particularly true for young people facing academic stress, family issues, or relationship difficulties, for whom games may be a way to seek comfort and relaxation.

Games are often designed to provide players with a sense of accomplishment and recognition for completing tasks, leveling up, or defeating opponents. Young people may become addicted to games because they offer a feeling of being appreciated and acknowledged, which they may lack in their real lives.

After getting older, they don’t like playing anymore

When young, individuals face fewer social responsibilities and pressures, allowing more time and energy for gaming. As they enter the workforce and start families, increased responsibilities make time and energy more valuable, potentially leading to gaming being seen as a time sink rather than a preferred leisure activity.

As people age, their cognitive abilities and interests evolve. What might appeal to someone in their youth—fast-paced, visually impressive games—may later give way to a preference for strategic, story-driven, or more complex experiences. If the market fails to meet these changing needs, interest will naturally decline.

item.title: Storing Custom Objects in Python Dictionaries: The Importance of References vs. Deep Copies
item.description:
In Python programming, dictionaries are a powerful data structure that allows us to associate key-value pairs and efficiently find and manipulate this data. When storing custom objects in a dictionary, we encounter a crucial concept: object assignment in Python is actually reference assignment, not a deep copy of the object itself. This means that when a custom object is placed into a dictionary, the dictionary stores a reference to that object, rather than a brand new copy.

Storing Custom Objects - Basic Example

Suppose we have a simple ____ class:

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age

# 创建一个 Person 对象
p1 = Person("Alice", 30)

# 将对象存储到字典中
people_dict = {}
people_dict["alice"] = p1

In this example, the attributes of INLINE_CODE_0 字典现在包含一个键为 INLINE_CODE_1 的项，其值是对 INLINE_CODE_2 类型的 p1 对象的引用。如果我们修改 p1:

p1.age = 31

When accessing this object through the dictionary, we find that its age has also been updated

print(people_dict["alice"].age)  # 输出：31

This is because the dictionary stores references to the same memory address, not independent copies of the objects

The difference between deep copy and shallow copy

This referencing behavior can lead to unexpected results when dealing with nested data structures or custom objects. For example, modifying an object directly stored in a dictionary—especially if it contains mutable attributes like lists or other custom objects—will affect the object retrieved through the dictionary.

class Address:
    def __init__(self, street, city):
        self.street = street
        self.city = city

class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age, address):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age
        self.address = address

address = Address("Main St.", "Springfield")
p1 = Person("Bob", 40, address)
people_dict["bob"] = p1

# 修改原始地址对象
address.city = "Shelbyville"

# 字典中的人的地址也变了
print(people_dict["bob"].address.city)  # 输出：Shelbyville

Please provide the Chinese text you want me to translate. I am ready when you are!

To avoid problems caused by this shared state, sometimes we need to ensure that the dictionary stores a complete copy of an object, rather than a reference. Python provides the copy() function to achieve this goal:

import copy

# 使用深拷贝存储对象
people_dict["bob_deepcopy"] = copy.deepcopy(p1)

# 此时即使修改原始地址对象，深拷贝的对象不会受影响
address.city = "Capital City"
print(people_dict["bob"].address.city)  # 输出：Capital City
print(people_dict["bob_deepcopy"].address.city)  # 输出：Shelbyville

When using dictionaries to store custom objects in Python, be mindful that object references are stored by default. For situations requiring independent state, use deep copying to avoid unexpected data changes due to shared references.
